entry.title: Resources for UPC visitors
entry.content:
Resources for UPC visitors

I have been told that some suggestions for visitors might be helpful so here they are.

Where is the Department?

The Computer Science Department location on the UPC campus is showed in the map on the left. It is easily reachable from the city center with the L3 (green line) and 3 minutes walk (a bit uphill). My office (223) and Albert’s (215) are on the second floor.

Where to eat?

In Barcelona there are a lot of amazing places where to eat and many many tourists traps. Below there is a short list of places with good food that are definitely not tourist traps. Most of the places listed below are vegetarian friendly.

Catalan and Spanish food

Bar Resolis: tapas bar in Gotic
El Xampaniet: tapas bar in Born
Carrer del Blai: street in Poble Sec with many pinchos bars
El Dinamic: catalan restaurant/bar in Raval

Paella

7 Portes: good paella place in Born
El Txiringuito de l’Escribà: paella place in Villa Olimpica (not Veg friendly)
Els Pescadors: paella place in PobleNou
Taberna El Glop: cheaper restaurant in Gracia that serves also reasonable Paella (also Veg frindly)

Pizza*

La Bella Napoli: pizza place in Poble Sec
Bo di Napoli: pizza place in Eixample
Napoletani DOC: down to Earth pizza place in Eixample
Sports Bar: down to Earth pizza place in Gotic (it is a restaurant despite the name)
*tested and approved by an Italian 🇮🇹 ;-)

Bars

La Monroe: hipster place for burgers, tapas, beers in Raval
Horel Barcelo’: roof top bar with nice view in Raval
Antic Teatre: place for beers in Born
Rekons: inexpensive empanadas in Raval
El Dinamic: catalan restaurant/bar in Raval

Vegetarian*

Rasoterra: vegetarian restaurant in Gotic
Aguaribay: vegetarian restaurant in PobleNou
Flax & Kale: chain of (highly)-vegetarian restaurants
*I don’t know yet good purely vegan places in Barcelona.

Other cuisines

El Pachuco: Mexican restaurant in Raval
Addis Abeba: Etiopian restaurant in Eixample
Cuina Deu: inexpensive Chinese restaurant in Raval (not really veg friendly)
Dionisos: chain of inexpensive Greek food
Mosquito: inexpensive Asian food in El Born

entry.title: Clique is hard on average for regular resolution

link.title: Clique is hard on average for regular resolution

entry.content:
All Talks ⇦

Clique is hard on average for regular resolution

Deciding whether a graph G with n vertices has a k-clique is one of the most basic computational problems on graphs. In this talk we show that certifying k-clique-freeness of Erdos-Renyi random graphs is hard for regular resolution. More precisely we show that for k«\sqrt{n} regular resolution asymptotically almost surely requires length n^{\Omega(k)} to establish that an Erdos-Renyi random graph (with appropriate edge density) does not contain a k-clique. This asymptotically optimal result implies unconditional lower bunds on the running time of several state-of-the-art algorithms used in practice.

Talks on this topic were given on:

Jul 27, 2018 Oford Complexity Day – Slides
Jul 20, 2018 RaTLoCC 2018: Ramsey Theory in Logic, Combinatorics and Complexity – Slides
Jun 28, 2018 50th Annual ACM Symposium on the Theory of Computing (STOC), Los Angeles CA – Poster
Jan 30, 2018 Dagstuhl Seminar 18051 – Proof Complexity – Slides

These talks are based on [1].

[1]Atserias, A., Bonacina, I., De Rezende, S., Lauria, M., Nordström, J. and Razborov, A. 2018. Clique Is Hard on Average for Regular Resolution. to appear in 50th Annual ACM SIGACT Symposium on the Theory of Computing (STOC’ 18) (2018). ⇨ doi

entry.title: Total space in resolution
entry.content:
All Talks ⇦

Total space in resolution

In this series of talks we cover some results on the space complexity of Resolution and in particular a connection between total space and width. Given a k-CNF formula F, the width is the minimal integer W such that there exists a Resolution refutation of with clauses of at most W literals. The total space is the minimal size T of a memory used to write down a Resolution refutation of F, where the size of the memory is measured as the total number of literals it can contain. We show that T=\Omega((W-k)^2). This connection between total space and width relies on some basic properties of another, perhaps less known, complexity measure in Resolution: the “asymmetric width”.

Talks on this theme were given on:

Feb 06, 2017 Universidad Politecnica de Catalunya – ALBCOM Seminar on Algorithms and Theory of Computation
Aug 19, 2016 Fields Institute, Toronto – Workshop on Theoretical Foundations of SAT Solving
Jul 14, 2016 43rd International Colloquium on Automata, Languages and Programming (ICALP)

entry.title: Strong size lower bounds in regular resolution via games

link.title: Strong size lower bounds in regular resolution via games

entry.content:
All Talks ⇦

Strong size lower bounds in regular resolution via games

The Strong Exponential Time Hypothesis (SETH) says that solving the SATISFIABILITY problem on formulas that are k-CNFs in n variables require running time 2^{(n(1 - c_k))} where c_k goes to 0 as k goes to infinity. Beck and Impagliazzo (2013) proved that regular resolution cannot disprove SETH, that is they prove that there are unsatisfiable k-CNF formulas in n variables such that each regular resolution refutation of those has size at least 2^{(n(1 - c_k))} where where c_k goes to 0 as k goes to infinity. We give a different/simpler proof of such lower bound based on the known characterizations of width and size in resolution and our technique indeed works for a proof system stronger than regular resolution. The problem of finding k-CNF formulas for which we can prove such strong size lower bounds in general resolution is still open.

Talks on this topic were given on:

Nov 21, 2016 KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm – Complexity Seminar* Sep 19, 2016 Dagstuhl Seminar 16381 – SAT and Interactions
Oct 01, 2015 Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya, Barcelona – Complexity Seminar
Jun 24, 2015 University of Edinburgh, UK – Complexity Seminar
Jun 17, 2015 University of Leeds, UK – Logic Seminar
Mar 21, 2014 KTH Royal Institute of Technology – Complexity Seminar (joint talk with Navid Talebanfard)

These talks are based on [1, 2, 3].

[1]Bonacina, I. and Talebanfard, N. 2016. Strong ETH and Resolution via Games and the Multiplicity of Strategies. Algorithmica. (Oct. 2016), 1–13. ⇨ doi

[2]Bonacina, I. and Talebanfard, N. 2016. Improving resolution width lower bounds for k-CNFs with applications to the Strong Exponential Time Hypothesis. Inf. Process. Lett. 116, 2 (2016), 120–124. ⇨ doi

[3]Bonacina, I. and Talebanfard, N. 2015. Strong ETH and Resolution via Games and the Multiplicity of Strategies. 10th International Symposium on Parameterized and Exact Computation – IPEC (2015), 248–257. ⇨ doi
